elements.content: A three-dimensional metal−organic framework [Cd3(μ4-mtta)3(N3)3]·2.5H2O with [Cd24(N3)24] tetraicosanuclear metallamacrocycle as secondary building units (SBUs) and helical character is formed by self-assembly and in situ ligand synthesis. Each tetraicosanuclear metallamacrocycle SBU connects to eight neighboring tetraicosanuclear metallamacrocycle SBUs through 5-methyl tetrazolate (mtta) ligands, resulting in a body-centered cubic (bcu) topology. Thermal stability, variable-temperature powder X-ray diffraction, and luminescence spectrum of the compound were also studied.
elements.clean_text: A three-dimensional metal-organic framework [Cd3(μ4-mtta)3(N3)3]⋅2.5H2O with [Cd24(N3)24] tetraicosanuclear metallamacrocycle as secondary building units (SBUs) and helical character is formed by self-assembly and in situ ligand synthesis. Each tetraicosanuclear metallamacrocycle SBU connects to eight neighboring tetraicosanuclear metallamacrocycle SBUs through 5-methyl tetrazolate (mtta) ligands, resulting in a body-centered cubic (bcu) topology. Thermal stability, variable-temperature powder X-ray diffraction, and luminescence spectrum of the compound were also studied.

elements.content: A three-dimensional coordinating metal−organic framework [Cd3(μ4-mtta)3(N3)3]·2.5H2O with a 48-membered tetraicosanuclear metallamacrocycle, shown in the figure with (Cd−N-)24 linkages highlighted in green by the thicker bonds, as secondary building units (SBUs) is formed with a body-centered cubic topology. The spherical unit is made of left- and right-handed double helical chains as walls with a pitch of 37.1046 Å running along a crystallgraphic 41 scew axis seen in the c direction. The thermal stability, guest desorption−sorption properties, variable-temperature in situ powder X-ray diffraction, and luminescence properties of the metal−organic framework were also studied.
elements.clean_text: A three-dimensional coordinating metal-organic framework [Cd3(μ4-mtta)3(N3)3]⋅2.5H2O with a 48-membered tetraicosanuclear metallamacrocycle, shown in the figure with (Cd-N-)24 linkages highlighted in green by the thicker bonds, as secondary building units (SBUs) is formed with a body-centered cubic topology. The spherical unit is made of left- and right-handed double helical chains as walls with a pitch of 37.1046 Å running along a crystallgraphic 41 scew axis seen in the c direction. The thermal stability, guest desorption-sorption properties, variable-temperature in situ powder X-ray diffraction, and luminescence properties of the metal-organic framework were also studied.

elements.content: Metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) have attracted much attention owing to their enormous variety of interesting framework topologies and wide potential applications such as gas storage and separation, catalysis, and sensors. Yaghi et al. have developed a secondary building unit (SBU) strategy to direct the assembly of MOFs, which has been widely used for understanding and predicting structural topologies. Although a large number of crystalline materials composed of SBUs and linkers have been reported, such topologies with eight connected nodes based on highly connected SBUs have only appeared in a few examples. Metal cluster selves as secondary building units (SBUs) have been proven as an effective and powerful synthetic strategy in constructing new MOFs, in which binuclear, trinuclear, and tetranuclear clusters are most commonly used. Furthermore, some novel MOFs with penta-, hexa-, octa-, undecanuclear (and even higher) SBUs have also been constructed in recent years. Depending on their architecture, MOFs based on polynuclear metallic units offer the potential for unique properties, such as host−guest, luminescence, magnetism, and catalysis. The synthetic challenge is to increase and control the degree of nuclearity of the metal clusters. Most of high nuclearity cluster itself is cagelike in its structure. The structure of most metallamacrocycles are composed of a few metals connected to a large ligand and hence the nuclearity of the metallamacrocycle is relatively low. Metallamacrocycles are important compounds due to their interesting molecular architectures, catalysis, sensor materials, magnets, and host−guest systems. Even though the topology of metallamacrocycle is simple, controlling their size and nuclearity properties remains a substantial challenge. It is also synthetically challenging to achieve metallamacrocycles with a high nuclearity. Thus, there continues to be a need for new synthetic methods for such molecules.
elements.clean_text: Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have attracted much attention owing to their enormous variety of interesting framework topologies and wide potential applications such as gas storage and separation, catalysis, and sensors. Yaghi et al. have developed a secondary building unit (SBU) strategy to direct the assembly of MOFs, which has been widely used for understanding and predicting structural topologies. Although a large number of crystalline materials composed of SBUs and linkers have been reported, such topologies with eight connected nodes based on highly connected SBUs have only appeared in a few examples. Metal cluster selves as secondary building units (SBUs) have been proven as an effective and powerful synthetic strategy in constructing new MOFs, in which binuclear, trinuclear, and tetranuclear clusters are most commonly used. Furthermore, some novel MOFs with penta-, hexa-, octa-, undecanuclear (and even higher) SBUs have also been constructed in recent years. Depending on their architecture, MOFs based on polynuclear metallic units offer the potential for unique properties, such as host-guest, luminescence, magnetism, and catalysis. The synthetic challenge is to increase and control the degree of nuclearity of the metal clusters. Most of high nuclearity cluster itself is cagelike in its structure. The structure of most metallamacrocycles are composed of a few metals connected to a large ligand and hence the nuclearity of the metallamacrocycle is relatively low. Metallamacrocycles are important compounds due to their interesting molecular architectures, catalysis, sensor materials, magnets, and host-guest systems. Even though the topology of metallamacrocycle is simple, controlling their size and nuclearity properties remains a substantial challenge. It is also synthetically challenging to achieve metallamacrocycles with a high nuclearity. Thus, there continues to be a need for new synthetic methods for such molecules.

elements.content: One productive avenue is to use chelates containing 5-methyl tetrazolate (mtta) or azide groups, as these are good bridging groups that can promote the formation of polynuclear products. Tetrazolate-based ligands have shown to be excellent and versatile building blocks, forming a great variety of supramolecular entities. Recently, Sharpless et al. reported the click chemistry for the synthesis of a variety of tetrazoles through [2 + 3] cycloaddition reactions of nitriles and azide in the presence of zinc salt as a Lewis acid. This synthetic approach has been extended by varying metal ions in the construction of coordination frameworks. Significant interest has also arisen in organic and coordination chemistry for the design and synthesis of novel coordination polymers with ligands generated in situ.
elements.clean_text: One productive avenue is to use chelates containing 5-methyl tetrazolate (mtta) or azide groups, as these are good bridging groups that can promote the formation of polynuclear products. Tetrazolate-based ligands have shown to be excellent and versatile building blocks, forming a great variety of supramolecular entities. Recently, Sharpless et al. reported the click chemistry for the synthesis of a variety of tetrazoles through [2 + 3] cycloaddition reactions of nitriles and azide in the presence of zinc salt as a Lewis acid. This synthetic approach has been extended by varying metal ions in the construction of coordination frameworks. Significant interest has also arisen in organic and coordination chemistry for the design and synthesis of novel coordination polymers with ligands generated in situ.

elements.content: In this present paper, we report the synthesis and the structural characterization of the MOF containing the largest known tetraicosanuclear as an SBU to form a three-dimensional (3D) polymeric network with body-centered cubic (bcu) topology and helical character by using Sharpless cycloaddition reactions of nitriles and azides. The MOF (1) is usually achieved by using bi- or multidentate ligands to connect the metal centers. The two types of coordinating ligands are (i) tetradentate ligand, for example, tetrazole, and (ii) bidentate ligand, for example, azide. However, to the best of our knowledge, MOFs based on the assembly of such a 48-membered tetraicosanuclear building units have not been reported. We have now discovered a higher nuclearity species, which in addition, possesses host−guest properties.
elements.clean_text: In this present paper, we report the synthesis and the structural characterization of the MOF containing the largest known tetraicosanuclear as an SBU to form a three-dimensional (3D) polymeric network with body-centered cubic (bcu) topology and helical character by using Sharpless cycloaddition reactions of nitriles and azides. The MOF (1) is usually achieved by using bi- or multidentate ligands to connect the metal centers. The two types of coordinating ligands are (i) tetradentate ligand, for example, tetrazole, and (ii) bidentate ligand, for example, azide. However, to the best of our knowledge, MOFs based on the assembly of such a 48-membered tetraicosanuclear building units have not been reported. We have now discovered a higher nuclearity species, which in addition, possesses host-guest properties.

elements.content: A mixture of Cd(ClO4)2·2H2O (3.0 mmol, 0.934 g), acetonitrile (3 mmol, 0.123 g), NaN3 (3 mmol, 0.195 g), ethanol (5 mL), and water (12 mL) was hydrothermally treated over a period of 72 h at 398 K, and then cooled (10 K h−1) to room temperature. Colorless crystals were obtained. The X-ray from the single-crystal analyses of [Cd3(μ4-mtta)3(N3)3]·2.5H2O (1) confirm the formation of 5-methyl tetrazolate. The complex 1 is composed of guest water molecules and a 3D neutral porous framework based on cadmium(II), the mtta and N3 ligand, with a space group of I4̅2m (Figure a and ). Approximately 20.2% of the crystal volume can be occupied by free water molecules, with a volume of ca. 9136.6 Å3 in each cell unit.
elements.clean_text: A mixture of Cd(ClO4)2⋅2H2O (3.0 mmol, 0.934 g), acetonitrile (3 mmol, 0.123 g), NaN3 (3 mmol, 0.195 g), ethanol (5 mL), and water (12 mL) was hydrothermally treated over a period of 72 h at 398 K, and then cooled (10 K h-1) to room temperature. Colorless crystals were obtained. The X-ray from the single-crystal analyses of [Cd3(μ4-mtta)3(N3)3]⋅2.5H2O (1) confirm the formation of 5-methyl tetrazolate. The complex 1 is composed of guest water molecules and a 3D neutral porous framework based on cadmium(II), the mtta and N3 ligand, with a space group of I4̅2m (Figure a and ). Approximately 20.2% of the crystal volume can be occupied by free water molecules, with a volume of ca. 9136.6 Å3 in each cell unit.

elements.content: (a) Wires/sticks (left) and polyhedral (right) representation the [Cd24(μ4-mtta)16(N3)24] of 1 viewed along the c axis. The included water molecules and methyl group of mtta and N2 of azide were omited for clarity. The (Cd−N-)24 linkages are highlighted by the thicker bonds as SBU. Cd: teal, C: white, N of mtta: blue, N of azide: green. (b) 3D structure of [Cd3(μ4-mtta)3(N3)3] (1), each SBU (polyhedral) of 1 is connected to eight adjacent SBUs (wires/sticks) through 20 mtta ligands, four mtta ligands are located within a SBU(thicker line); right: viewed along the c axis. left: viewed along the a axis. The included water molecules and methyl group and N2 of azide were omitted for clarity. (c) Right: perspective view of a [Cd24N24] SBU (green) with eight adjacent neighbors (pink) of 1 in the cell unit. Left: schematic representation of bcu topology of eight-connected framework of 1; the bcu cell is indicated by red lines; SBU are represented as green spheres.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Wires/sticks (left) and polyhedral (right) representation the [Cd24(μ4-mtta)16(N3)24] of 1 viewed along the c axis. The included water molecules and methyl group of mtta and N2 of azide were omited for clarity. The (Cd-N-)24 linkages are highlighted by the thicker bonds as SBU. Cd: teal, C: white, N of mtta: blue, N of azide: green. (b) 3D structure of [Cd3(μ4-mtta)3(N3)3] (1), each SBU (polyhedral) of 1 is connected to eight adjacent SBUs (wires/sticks) through 20 mtta ligands, four mtta ligands are located within a SBU(thicker line); right: viewed along the c axis. left: viewed along the a axis. The included water molecules and methyl group and N2 of azide were omitted for clarity. (c) Right: perspective view of a [Cd24N24] SBU (green) with eight adjacent neighbors (pink) of 1 in the cell unit. Left: schematic representation of bcu topology of eight-connected framework of 1; the bcu cell is indicated by red lines; SBU are represented as green spheres.

elements.content: All of the cadmium atoms in the structure of 1 have octahedral coordination environments (). As shown in Figure a, the CdII-centered octahedral are linked together by 24 μ4-mtta and 24 μ2-N3 moieties to build up a tetraicosanuclear [Cd24(μ4-mtta)24(N3)24]. A better insight into the structure of [Cd24(μ4-mtta)24(N3)24] can be obtained by reducing mtta ligands to a simple [Cd24(N3)24] metallamacrocycle (). As shown in , the azide ligand bridges the cadmium atom through μ-1,1-EO mode to form a 48-membered ring. These tetraicosanuclear metallamacrocycles, which behave as SBUs, are interconnected through the tetrazolate ligands to generate an extended 3D framework (). Other better insight into the structure of 1 can be obtained by the standard procedure of reducing multidimensional structures to simple node-and-linker reference nets known as the topological approach. As shown in Figure b, each tetraicosanuclear SBU in 1 is connected to adjacent SBUs through 20 mtta ligands, and four mtta ligands are located within a SBU. Therefore, each SBU of 1 can be defined as an eight-connected node. As mtta only acts as a bridging ligand, there is no need to consider it in the topological analysis. On the basis of this simplification, the structure of 1 can be described as an eight-connected 3D network with the Schläfli symbol (424·64), which corresponds to a bcu topology that is rare for MOFs (Figure c). Schröder and Champness prepared the first eight-connected bcu nets in 2001. To our knowledge, this MOF has the largest transition-metal cluster as SBUs and the highest nuclearity metal/azide metallamacrocycle reported to date.
elements.clean_text: All of the cadmium atoms in the structure of 1 have octahedral coordination environments (). As shown in Figure a, the CdII-centered octahedral are linked together by 24 μ4-mtta and 24 μ2-N3 moieties to build up a tetraicosanuclear [Cd24(μ4-mtta)24(N3)24]. A better insight into the structure of [Cd24(μ4-mtta)24(N3)24] can be obtained by reducing mtta ligands to a simple [Cd24(N3)24] metallamacrocycle (). As shown in , the azide ligand bridges the cadmium atom through μ-1,1-EO mode to form a 48-membered ring. These tetraicosanuclear metallamacrocycles, which behave as SBUs, are interconnected through the tetrazolate ligands to generate an extended 3D framework (). Other better insight into the structure of 1 can be obtained by the standard procedure of reducing multidimensional structures to simple node-and-linker reference nets known as the topological approach. As shown in Figure b, each tetraicosanuclear SBU in 1 is connected to adjacent SBUs through 20 mtta ligands, and four mtta ligands are located within a SBU. Therefore, each SBU of 1 can be defined as an eight-connected node. As mtta only acts as a bridging ligand, there is no need to consider it in the topological analysis. On the basis of this simplification, the structure of 1 can be described as an eight-connected 3D network with the Schläfli symbol (424⋅64), which corresponds to a bcu topology that is rare for MOFs (Figure c). Schröder and Champness prepared the first eight-connected bcu nets in 2001. To our knowledge, this MOF has the largest transition-metal cluster as SBUs and the highest nuclearity metal/azide metallamacrocycle reported to date.

elements.content: The spherical part in Figure a contains four different SBU units and is composed of helical chains. The helical channels are made of two right- and two left-handed quadruple helical chains as walls with a pitch of 37.1046 Å running along a crystallographic 41 screw axis in the c direction, and the Cd3 atoms are located at the intersecting points of the left- and right-hand quadruple helical chains. Each single-helical chain has a Cd3−Cd2−Cd1−Cd3−Cd3−Cd1−Cd2−Cd3 repeating unit by a square shown in Figure b. The approximate dimension of the tube is 9.59 × 9.59 Å2. It consists of two same handed (both right- and left-handed) helical strands that entangle each other through the cross-link of 4-connected mtta.
elements.clean_text: The spherical part in Figure a contains four different SBU units and is composed of helical chains. The helical channels are made of two right- and two left-handed quadruple helical chains as walls with a pitch of 37.1046 Å running along a crystallographic 41 screw axis in the c direction, and the Cd3 atoms are located at the intersecting points of the left- and right-hand quadruple helical chains. Each single-helical chain has a Cd3-Cd2-Cd1-Cd3-Cd3-Cd1-Cd2-Cd3 repeating unit by a square shown in Figure b. The approximate dimension of the tube is 9.59 × 9.59 Å2. It consists of two same handed (both right- and left-handed) helical strands that entangle each other through the cross-link of 4-connected mtta.

elements.content: (a) Polyhedron structure of compound 1 viewed along the c axis. (left) View of 1D column architecture coiled by four interecting helices. (middle) The helical channel with two-interwined right-handed and left-handed single-helical chains as walls. (right) (b) Polyhedron structure of a single helical. The square is a repeating unit. Cd1: yellow; Cd2: green; Cd3: pink.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) Polyhedron structure of compound 1 viewed along the c axis. (left) View of 1D column architecture coiled by four interecting helices. (middle) The helical channel with two-interwined right-handed and left-handed single-helical chains as walls. (right) (b) Polyhedron structure of a single helical. The square is a repeating unit. Cd1: yellow; Cd2: green; Cd3: pink.

elements.content: The compound is insoluble in common organic solvents and water. The porous frameworks both exhibit high robustness and thermal stability (). The TGA curve indicates that a weight loss of lattice water (2.5H2O) molecules (calcd 5.95%; found 5.82%) occurs at about 300 °C and the compound begins decomposition at temperatures above 300 °C. The complex is decomposed at above 500 °C to give a CdO residue (calcd. 50.85%; found 51.35%).
elements.clean_text: The compound is insoluble in common organic solvents and water. The porous frameworks both exhibit high robustness and thermal stability (). The TGA curve indicates that a weight loss of lattice water (2.5H2O) molecules (calcd 5.95%; found 5.82%) occurs at about 300 °C and the compound begins decomposition at temperatures above 300 °C. The complex is decomposed at above 500 °C to give a CdO residue (calcd. 50.85%; found 51.35%).

elements.content: To study guest desorption−sorption properties, the repeated heating−cooling TG measurement of compound 1 was performed. The results depicted in Figure shows a completely reversible cyclic process. As shown in Figure , reabsorption takes place after approximately 300 min. However, only about 85% of the water molecules were reabsorbed. To achieve total reabsorption, the compound was thus left for a day for in situ powder X-ray diffraction. The dehydration and rehydration process has also been studied by variable-temperature in situ powder X-ray diffraction. The pattern for dehydration at 300 °C shows that the sample remains crystalline and that reabsorption by expose to air at an ambient temperature for a day confirms that the integrity of the framework is not affected by the release of water molecules ().
elements.clean_text: To study guest desorption-sorption properties, the repeated heating-cooling TG measurement of compound 1 was performed. The results depicted in Figure  shows a completely reversible cyclic process. As shown in Figure , reabsorption takes place after approximately 300 min. However, only about 85% of the water molecules were reabsorbed. To achieve total reabsorption, the compound was thus left for a day for in situ powder X-ray diffraction. The dehydration and rehydration process has also been studied by variable-temperature in situ powder X-ray diffraction. The pattern for dehydration at 300 °C shows that the sample remains crystalline and that reabsorption by expose to air at an ambient temperature for a day confirms that the integrity of the framework is not affected by the release of water molecules ().

elements.content: The TGA measurements of compound 1 of cyclic dehydration and rehydration processes were repeated three times. Solid line: the variation of weight loss with time; dashed line: the variation of temperature with time.
elements.clean_text: 3  The TGA measurements of compound 1 of cyclic dehydration and rehydration processes were repeated three times. Solid line: the variation of weight loss with time; dashed line: the variation of temperature with time.

elements.content: The fluorescence of the as-synthesized compound was studied in its solid state at room temperature (see ), and an intense blue emission at about 380 nm was observed (λex = 314 nm). This is ascribed to the cooperative effects of intraligand emission and ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT).
elements.clean_text: The fluorescence of the as-synthesized compound was studied in its solid state at room temperature (see ), and an intense blue emission at about 380 nm was observed (λex = 314 nm). This is ascribed to the cooperative effects of intraligand emission and ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT).

elements.content: In this article, we report the successful synthesis of the porous, open-framework complex [Cd3(μ4-mtta)3(N3)3]·2.5H2O (1), which contains the largest known tetraicosanuclear Cd24−N24 SBU, and the highest nuclearity metal/azide metallamacrocycle, and has a rare bcu topology, by rationally utilizing a flexible azide (N3)) as a strong bridging ligand. The compound [Cd3(μ4-mtta)3(N3)3]·2.5H2O (1) also shows host−guest properties. Moreover, this work emphasizes the coordinative flexibility and versatility of the mixed ligand and its synthetic utility in polynuclear metal chemistry. We believe this work presages a new area of higher nuclearity metallamacrocycle products than is currently known.
elements.clean_text: In this article, we report the successful synthesis of the porous, open-framework complex [Cd3(μ4-mtta)3(N3)3]⋅2.5H2O (1), which contains the largest known tetraicosanuclear Cd24-N24 SBU, and the highest nuclearity metal/azide metallamacrocycle, and has a rare bcu topology, by rationally utilizing a flexible azide (N3)) as a strong bridging ligand. The compound [Cd3(μ4-mtta)3(N3)3]⋅2.5H2O (1) also shows host-guest properties. Moreover, this work emphasizes the coordinative flexibility and versatility of the mixed ligand and its synthetic utility in polynuclear metal chemistry. We believe this work presages a new area of higher nuclearity metallamacrocycle products than is currently known.

elements.content: Synthesis, ORTEP, 48-membered tetraicosanuclear metallamacrocyle as SBU, polyhedra structure, room-temperature and variable-temperature in situ PXRD, TGA curve, and luminescence spectrum. Crystallographic file in CIF format (ccdc 702846). This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.
elements.clean_text: Synthesis, ORTEP, 48-membered tetraicosanuclear metallamacrocyle as SBU, polyhedra structure, room-temperature and variable-temperature in situ PXRD, TGA curve, and luminescence spectrum. Crystallographic file in CIF format (ccdc 702846). This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

cln_elements.content:
A mixture of Cd(ClO4)2·2H2O (3.0 mmol, 0.934 g), acetonitrile (3 mmol, 0.123 g), NaN3 (3 mmol, 0.195 g), ethanol (5 mL), and water (12 mL) was hydrothermally treated over a period of 72 h at 398 K, and then cooled (10 K h−1) to room temperature. Colorless crystals were obtained. The X-ray from the single-crystal analyses of [Cd3(μ4-mtta)3(N3)3]·2.5H2O (1) confirm the formation of 5-methyl tetrazolate. The complex 1 is composed of guest water molecules and a 3D neutral porous framework based on cadmium(II), the mtta and N3 ligand, with a space group of I4̅2m (Figure a and ). Approximately 20.2% of the crystal volume can be occupied by free water molecules, with a volume of ca. 9136.6 Å3 in each cell unit.

The compound is insoluble in common organic solvents and water. The porous frameworks both exhibit high robustness and thermal stability (). The TGA curve indicates that a weight loss of lattice water (2.5H2O) molecules (calcd 5.95%; found 5.82%) occurs at about 300 °C and the compound begins decomposition at temperatures above 300 °C. The complex is decomposed at above 500 °C to give a CdO residue (calcd. 50.85%; found 51.35%).

Colorless crystals were obtained. The X-ray from the single-crystal analyses of [Cd3(μ4-mtta)3(N3)3]⋅2.5H2O (1) confirm the formation of 5-methyl tetrazolate. The complex 1 is composed of guest water molecules and a 3D neutral porous framework based on cadmium(II), the mtta and N3 ligand, with a space group of I4̅2m (Figure a and ). Approximately 20.2% of the crystal volume can be occupied by free water molecules, with a volume of ca. 9136.6 Å3 in each cell unit. 

The compound is insoluble in common organic solvents and water. The porous frameworks both exhibit high robustness and thermal stability (). The TGA curve indicates that a weight loss of lattice water (2.5H2O) molecules (calcd 5.95%; found 5.82%) occurs at about 300 °C and the compound begins decomposition at temperatures above 300 °C. The complex is decomposed at above 500 °C to give a CdO residue (calcd. 50.85%; found 51.35%).

decomposition temperature.type: weight loss of lattice water molecules
decomposed to give a CdO residue

metadata.title:
A Three-Dimensional Porous Metal−Organic Framework with a Body-Centered Cubic Topology Constructed from 48-Membered Tetraicosanuclear Metallamacrocycle Based on in Situ Ligand Synthesis
Communications
